title: How to Make Old Bay Seasoning

steps.headline: Gather your ingredients.
steps.description: To make Old Bay, you need many different types of spices. You probably have several of these in your pantry already, but you may have to seek out the remaining ones at your local grocery store, spice shop, or online. If you can’t find ground versions of some of the spices, you can buy them whole and grind them yourself with a mortar and pestle or an electric spice grinder.

steps.headline: Mix the spices in the recommended quantities.
steps.description:
The recipe is pretty simple once you’ve found all of the ingredients. Just dump them all in a bowl in the following amounts:
2 tablespoons (30 mL) ground bay leaves
2 tablespoons (30 mL) celery salt
1 tablespoon (15 mL) dry mustard
2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) ground black pepper
2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) ground ginger
2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) sweet paprika
1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) ground white pepper
1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) ground nutmeg
1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) ground cloves
1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) ground allspice

⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) crushed red pepper flakes

⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) ground mace

⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) ground cardamom

steps.headline: Adjust the spice ratios based on your own preferences.
steps.description: If you know you like or dislike some of the spices in the recipe, adjust accordingly. You can also use more of certain spices to bring out certain flavor profiles. Try out your Old Bay seasoning once you’ve blended everything, and add more spices one at a time to suit your tastes. To give your Old Bay a tangier taste, add more mustard. If you love the taste and nostalgic qualities of warm baking spices, use more nutmeg, cloves, and allspice. To bring out a more floral, grassy flavor, add more celery salt. If you like things spicy, add up to double the amounts of paprika and black, white, and red peppers.

steps.headline: Use freshly ground spices for maximum flavor.
steps.description: Whenever possible, use whole spices and grind them yourself before using. Ground spices typically last for about 6 months before they need to be replaced, while whole spices can last up to 5 years. You can grind whole spices by hand with a mortar and pestle. You can also use an electric spice grinder to make it easier. Alternately, you can use a coffee grinder. Make sure to clean it out thoroughly first, or use a separate coffee grinder for your spices to avoid making them taste like coffee.

methods.name: Making and Grinding Old Bay Ingredients

steps.headline: Make bay leaf powder by toasting and grinding dried leaves.
steps.description: Heat dried bay leaves in a skillet for a minute or two, tossing them regularly to prevent burning. Let the leaves cool, and then grind with a mortar and pestle or a spice grinder.

steps.headline: Create celery salt by combining celery powder and table salt.
steps.description: Blend them together in approximately equal amounts. If you’d rather have more salt in your Old Bay, you can mix a 2:1 ratio of salt to celery powder, and use this blend in place of celery salt. If you don’t have celery powder, or if you’d rather use the freshest possible spices, you can make it yourself by blending celery seeds in a grinder.

steps.headline: Make ground ginger by dicing, drying, and grinding fresh ginger.
steps.description: Wash off fresh ginger root, and then use a sharp knife to dice it into tiny pieces. Spread them out on a plate in the sun for several hours. Once all the pieces are dry, use a spice grinder or food processor to blend the ginger into a powder and put it through a sieve to remove large chunks. You can also dry the ginger in a dehydrator. Alternately, dry it in your oven by spreading out diced ginger on a baking sheet and heating it in your oven for up to 10 hours on the lowest oven setting with the door cracked open. Remove the ginger once it’s completely dry.

steps.headline: Store your seasoning in an airtight container.
steps.description: Try using Mason jars, small plastic food storage containers, or old spice jars. Make sure you tightly close the lid each time after using your Old Bay to keep it fresh.

steps.headline: Keep Old Bay in a cool, dark place.
steps.description: The more spices are exposed to heat and light, the quicker they lose their potency. Keep your spice blend in a pantry or cupboard with the door closed. If possible, avoid storing your spices in a place near a heat source, such as a cupboard over your stove, to make them last longer.

steps.headline: Make small quantities so you can use the mix before it goes bad.
steps.description: Spices lose their potency over time. A good rule of thumb is to try to use all of your Old Bay within 6 months. Check the expiration dates of all of the ground spices you add to your seasoning mix to get an idea of how long you have until your Old Bay loses flavor. Use sight and smell to keep track of how potent your Old Bay is. If the spices’ colors appear faded, or if they seem less fragrant, you may have to use more Old Bay in your recipe to get the flavor you expect.

steps.headline: Perk up your seasoning by toasting it in a dry skillet.
steps.description: If your Old Bay is a little bit older and losing some of its flavor, add it to a dry skillet and toast it for a minute while moving the skillet back and forth. As soon as you begin to smell the spices, remove the mix from heat. This can help bring back some of its flavor. If this method doesn’t help, and your Old Bay seasoning lacks flavor even after toasting, it may be too old. It is probably time to mix up a new batch.

steps.headline: Steam seafood in Old Bay.
steps.description: Dump your seasoning into a pot of boiling water, and then add shrimp, crabs, or other seafood. The spices will flavor the meat as it cooks. Combine ⁄2 cup (120 mL) water, ⁄2 cup (120 mL) vinegar, and 2 tablespoons (30 mL) Old Bay in a pot. Boil, add 1 pound (0.45 kg) of shrimp, and cook for 2-3 minutes. Add equal parts water and vinegar to a stock pot. Put 12 live crabs in a steamer basket or rack on top of the pot, cover with ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of Old Bay, and steam for 20-30 minutes.

steps.headline: Serve a combination of Old Bay and vinegar to use as a dip.
steps.description: Add white vinegar to Old Bay gradually until you get a mixture that has a paste consistency. Serve it in a bowl on your table, and dip seafood like crab and shrimp into it.

steps.headline: Fry meat or seafood with an Old Bay coating.
steps.description: Mix Old Bay into flour, and dredge your chicken or fish in it. You can then pan fry in a small amount of oil, or fry the whole piece of meat in a deep fryer. Add 1 tablespoon (15 mL) Old Bay seasoning to ⁄4 cup (180 mL) potato starch, coat chicken wings in the mixture, and fry them.

steps.headline: Mix Old Bay into soups and stews.
steps.description: The warmth of allspice and cloves and the spiciness of pepper and paprika provides great seasoning for a warm, hearty stew in the winter. Alternately, a small amount of Old Bay can complement a lighter seafood chowder or give a tangier taste to a gazpacho for a warm-weather meal. For example, add 2 tablespoons (30 mL) Old Bay into a seafood chowder in place of other seasonings.

steps.headline: Spruce up your snacks with Old Bay.
steps.description: This spice blend tastes great on a fresh batch of popcorn or french fries. Sprinkle Old Bay on air popped or microwaved popcorn, along with a little bit of butter, or toss Old Bay with sliced potatoes before baking them.

steps.headline: Add Old Bay to a Bloody Mary.
steps.description:
Sprinkle Old Bay seasoning directly into your drink, or mix it into a store-bought or homemade Bloody Mary Mix. For extra flavor, add Old Bay to the rim of your glass. To make your own Bloody Mary mix, combine the following in a blender and chill before serving:
8 large tomatoes
1 medium chopped carrot
The juice of 1 lemon
4 tablespoons (59 mL) of mild hot sauce
1 tablespoon (15 mL) horseradish
1 teaspoon (4.9 mL)of mustard powder
1 teaspoon (4.9 mL)grated ginger

⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of your Old Bay mix

steps.headline: Give away your homemade seasoning blend as a gift.
steps.description: Make up a large batch of Old Bay, divide it into small jars or airtight containers, and give it to friends, family, or co-workers during the holidays. If you have a favorite recipe that uses Old Bay, type or write it out and attach it to the jar.
